title: Thursday, 8th December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Damn, look at the time.

BE11:06am

Unfortunately, I've been doing my proper job all morning so am a bit under-prepared for this one.

BE11:06am

Still, we push on regardless. Have a picture.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:07am

Beyoncé, with an acute accent.

BE11:08am

She's on the quite long shortlist for FT's Woman of the Year.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

https://www.ft.com/women-of-the-year

BE11:09am

Though if it's going to be decided by reader comments, Theresa May (82) will probably beat Beyonce (zero).

BE11:10am

Park Geun-hye has one comment. As does Margrethe Vestager. Kellyanne Conway has four. Phoebe Waller-Bridge & Vicky Jones get two.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Everyone else -- including Mary Berry! -- zero.

BE11:11am

(A. M.: perhaps you've entered a time portal..)

BE11:12am

You're a strange mob, readers. Anyway, enough of that waffle.

11:11 am
undefined
BE11:12am

So we'll get onto the wave of profit warnings and quasi profit warnings in a bit, but there's fun with FOBTs to cover first.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 288.27, down 23.23 (-7.46%), High: 303.60, Low: 283.60, Volume: 4.29m
11:12 am
Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 118.43, down 8.67 (-6.82%), High: 125.00, Low: 112.10, Volume: 11.40m
Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 8,170, down 60 (-0.73%), High: 8,250, Low: 8,150, Volume: 48.60k
BE11:13am

I don't think we have the actual Parliamentary report yet .....

11:13 am
BE11:13am

..... but we have the chair of the all-party committee tweeting the Times story about it, so let's assume it's fairly accurate.

BE11:13am

https://twitter.com/carolynharris24/status/806778639429685249

BE11:14am

Here's the link: http://www.thetime...s-demand-kl6lkqjvj

11:14 am
BE11:14am

A cross-party group of MPs will today demand stricter controls on betting machines that allow punters to lose £300 a minute on casino games.

BE11:14am

The fixed odds betting terminals all-party parliamentary group will publish the findings of a six-month inquiry into the machines.

Its report says that there is a “prima facie” case to cut the maximum stake of £100 a spin. It also urges ministers to slow the speed with which punters can make bets from once every 20 seconds. The report is significant because it is supported by MPs from all the main parties, including the senior Conservative backbencher Sir Peter Bottomley.

BE11:15am

Also talks about FOBT stake reductions "on a precautionary basis”, "at the very least".

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Sees "a strong case for the stake being set at £2"

BE11:16am

And will also recommend the government consider a reduction in machine numbers per shop and/or a reduction in the current bet timer of 20 seconds.

BE11:16am

Cutting to £2 has long been considered the worst-case scenario for the bookies.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Though in the context of how much bookies are raking in here, that oft-quoted £300-a-minute figure is worth taking apart.

BE11:17am

It's based on the max stake of £100 and one spin lasting the regulatory minimum of 20 seconds.

BE11:17am

So, to lose £300 a minute you'd need to bet the maximum on a roulette spin and lose five consecutive times.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Which is possible! Students of Martingale know it's possible.

BE11:18am

But it'd be unlucky when the house's gross win margin is 2.7%.

BE11:18am

So anyway, the trade says a typical roulette session results in gross win to the shop (and therefore a loss to the punter) of around £7.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Based on that 2.7% gross win, that's a total cumulative stake of £260 or thereabouts.

BE11:19am

Taking an average roulette session of eight minutes -- which seems to be the industry's best guess -- that indicates an average stake per spin of just over £10.

BE11:20am

Which looks about right based on this old Gambling Commission data.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

BE11:20am

Here's a very old Cazenove note -- as in, 2014! Quite seriously out of date, warning! Danger -- doing the maths on stake limits.

BE11:20am

11:20 am
BE11:20am

(Open in new tab to make legible.)

BE11:21am

(@Arash: FFS.)

BE11:21am

Importantly, though, that's before the introduction of the £50 journey in April 2015

11:21 am
BE11:21am

........ Which forced anyone staking £50 staking on machines to load them over the counter or have an account.

BE11:21am

Hill said the volume of stakes over £50 materially fell when the "journey" was introduced.

BE11:22am

Also remember that bookies have recently been pushing B3 machines -- as in, the type they put in bingo halls -- which already impose a £2 limit.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

William Hill says 35% of machine gross win now comes from B3 machines, which probably aren't part of the coming triennial review on bookmakers.

BE11:22am

Ladbrokes says 40% mix coming from B3.

BE11:23am

More generally though .....

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Machines are what has replaced over-the-counter betting and -- according to the industry at least -- keep our high streets thriving in spite of bets moving online.

BE11:23am

Machine rake has grown every year except 2008 and 2015.

BE11:23am

11:25 am
BE11:25am

(@Flaneur: Sky only owns 20% of Sky Bet, which is online only and worth about 0.2p a share in total according to Morgan Stanley. I don't think it's a big swing factor here.)

BE11:26am

So anyway, here's the basic hit for B2 limits, via UBS .....

BE11:26am

William Hill .....

11:25 am
BE11:26am

BE11:26am

And Ladbrokes ......

BE11:26am

11:26 am
BE11:26am

That assumes "customers who were staking above any newly imposed limit previously would reduce their staking amount to the new limit, with no change to frequency of play or length of play."

BE11:27am

......... which might be unrealistic, given the tendency for compulsive gamblers to find a way to lose their money in any way possible.

BE11:27am

And it does seem to be compulsive gamblers we're talking about now.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

The "journey" stuff seems to have cut off the potential for amateur money-laundering that we've talked about in the past.

undefined
BE11:29am

KKR TO LAUNCH VOLUNTARY PUBLIC TENDER OFFER FOR GfK SE

11:29 am
BE11:29am

London & Nuremberg, 8 December 2016 – Acceleratio Capital N.V., a holding company controlled by funds advised by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. L.P. (together with affiliates, “KKR”), today announced its intention to make a voluntary public tender offer for the shares (ISIN: DE0005875306) of GfK SE (“GfK”).

GfK is a leading global market research company, listed on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. By turning big data into smart data, GfK enables clients such as major advertisers, consumer goods manufacturers and broadcasters to improve their competitive edge and enrich consumers’ experiences and choices.

The offer price will be EUR 43.50 per share. Under the terms of the public tender offer, holders of GfK shares will receive a premium of about 44 percent on the estimated volume weighted three-month average price of GfK’s shares prior to the announcement.

GfK Verein as the majority shareholder in GfK welcomes KKR and supports its strategy. Accordingly, Acceleratio Capital N.V. and GfK Verein, today signed a shareholder agreement, outlining how they will work together following a successful tender offer to jointly develop the company further. In this context, it was agreed that GfK Verein will not tender any shares into the offer and remain majority shareholder with a stake of 56.46 percent.

BE11:29am

Well ...... let's just say that's five days of work down the swanee.

undefined
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Onto profit warnings, then .......

BE11:30am

Sports Direct mentioned on the right

BE11:31am

(@Gross Loydman: you'd be banned with extreme prejudice. I suggest you don't try it.)

11:31 am
Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 287.82, down 27.08 (-8.60%), High: 309.20, Low: 278.50, Volume: 2.74m
BE11:31am

Ashley really doesn't make life easy on himself.

BE11:32am

H1 results are appalling. Even worse than expected.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

So what better time to buy Ash Force One?

BE11:33am

Corporate assets and facilities

To facilitate efficiencies relating to the use of management time and the pursuit of the Group's strategic priorities, the Group will be taking delivery of a corporate plane in the coming weeks. It will form part of the Group's corporate assets and facilities, which include:

· A corporate helicopter which is used by senior management, employees and our business partners on a regular basis to visit and connect with our people across our 500+ sites and partner offices throughout the UK;

· A fleet of corporate vehicles which are used to transport employees and business partners to our sites across the UK; and,

· The Best Western Lion Hotel in Worksop and several houses in and around Shirebrook which are used to accommodate employees and business partners on their work visits to our Shirebrook campus. Employees, including the Chief Executive, whose work base is Shirebrook, but who choose to use Company accommodation, pay rent.

BE11:33am

Each of the Group's assets and facilities are managed by protocols and procedures which are focused on utilising each for maximum commercial benefit, and their use is reviewed at regular intervals in line with the Group's protocols. The plane is being acquired at a total cost of $51.1m, and to ensure efficient use of this asset and the Group's helicopter the Group also enables these to be chartered at open market rates by third parties or staff in a personal capacity if they are not being used by the Group. The Board believes that these corporate assets generate substantial operational benefits for the Company and enable Sports Direct to operate efficiently across its global footprint.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Good morning, welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily this thing with the numbers and stuff.

BE11:35am

Canaccord maintains sell.

BE11:35am

H1 underlying PBT -57%
Sports Direct reported H1 underlying EBITDA, down 34% to £145.3m versus our estimate of £156m. We are not aware of a formal consensus for H1 expectations. H1 PBT was down by more, -57% to £71.6m (CGe £102m), reflecting an increase in the depreciation charge.
The H1 group gross margin was worse than we expected, down 450bps (CGe -400bps), a function of sterling weakness.
In addition, due in part to changes in policy, depreciation in H1 increased by £23.5m and the FY charge is expected to be c. £130m (vs CGe £120m). There has also been an increase in provisioning on slow moving stock.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Following a re-appraisal of the European business, and in combination with weak fx, management expects a 'sustained weak performance' from this business over the medium term. H1 saw an increase in onerous lease provisions for Europe of £15.6m. While the focus is on fixing the core, 'the Board believes it prudent to pause on actively pursuing strategic acquisitions and investments'. Wholly sensible, in our view, but growth in Europe had been a key part of the longer-term investment case.

BE11:36am

The company is guiding to FY17E EBITDA 'around the bottom of the range' implied in the 7 October announcement of £265m-£285m. Despite this, it remains committed to c. £300m pa in freehold property investments over the next 2-4yrs.
Our FY17E EBITDA of £263m is in line with this guidance and c6% below consensus (wide range). CGe FY17E PBT is £141.5m (18.4p). We expect consensus at least to fall in line with guidance given today's announcement. The shares trade on a calendar 2017E PE of 17.4x. Our 231p price target is based on applying 0.9x FY17E ROCE/WACC to average capital employed.

BE11:37am

RBC ...........

11:37 am
BE11:37am

[V]ery poor gross margin performance. H1 gross margin was down -450bps compared to our -400bps estimate owing to dollar sourcing pressure and increased clearance activity following a build up of inventories. In particular, the UK sports retail gross margin was down -610bps. SPD decided not to
hedge its USD buy between USD/£ 1.60 and 1.20 when it became almost half hedged. SPD has acquired the remainder of its GBP/USD needs for FY17 at an average rate of 1.2630 but remains unhedged for FY18 and beyond. Inventory is +13% yoy at H1, an improvement on the +36% yoy position reported at the full year.

BE11:37am

Our view: Underperform, 240p PT. We remain cautious on Sports Direct given our FY18/19 EBITDA forecasts are 10-15% below consensus. We think it will be challenging for Sports Direct to grow profits in FY18 owing to the impact of dollar sourcing headwinds on own brand product bought from Asia
(c.50% of sales) and higher operating expenses. We think it will be difficult for Sports Direct to pass on currency headwinds without a significant volume impact given discount shoppers tend to be very price sensitive. Also the sporting calendar is weaker in FY18 and Sports Direct is likely to face UK consumer headwinds given inflation pressures on UK household cashflow. Finally we see a risk of higher than expected markdown given high inventories.
We have a 240p price target for Sports Direct based on DCF analysis. We see a take-private scenario as unlikely given a CY17E P/E of c.18x.

BE11:37am

Ashley reiterates he's not taking it private, incidentally.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Because, I mean, why bother? He can buy a jet anyway.

BE11:39am

There was a buyer out there ... I'm sure there was .....

BE11:39am

Ah, Jonathan Pritchard of Peel Hunt.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Sports Direct’s Interims were predictably X-certificate and
forecasts will fall today. However, in amongst the pages of
promises on working practices (and the Sports Direct family)
and corporate governance, there is some interesting rhetoric on
strategy. Mr Ashley is reinforcing the commitment to improve
relations with suppliers and the devotion of £300m pa to
purchasing freeholds is a decent statement of intent. It was
probably too hopeful to expect the planets to have aligned today
so that new executives could be announced but a couple of
strong new recruits would help the buy case further. It will take
time for SPD to turn around the business and its forecast
momentum but we believe that the strategic changes make this
very interesting. Buy.

BE11:40am

That looks increasingly like a brave call.

undefined
11:41 am
BE11:41am

There was a request for ECB previews ......

BE11:42am

As per today's meeting. Consensus is for QE extension, right?

BE11:42am

So says Davy anyway.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Today’s ECB meeting is expected to settle on an extension of asset purchases beyond the March 2017 end-date - perhaps for a further six months to September 2017. The ECB could also increase the current €80bn per month purchase limit but might struggle to find eligible bonds due to the self-imposed limits built into the programme. These include rules on the proportion of a nation’s sovereign debt the ECB can hold (capital key) and a 33% limit on the proportion of a particular bond held. The bank could also decide to buy debt with yields below its current deposit rate of 0.4% - freeing up German bonds for purchase in particular - but this would in effect mean making a loss on these holdings and is therefore unlikely to happen.
Also unlikely is the Governing Council agreeing to begin purchasing Greek debt, despite a fresh deal on its bailout programme being struck earlier in the week by the Eurogroup. The IMF has once again declined to participate in the programme due to concerns on the strength of structural reforms, which may also preclude the ECB from including Greek debt in its asset purchase programme just yet.

BE11:43am

The decision to extend exceptional monetary support may not be unanimous. Hawks on the Governing Council will point to strengthening GDP growth and rising inflation expectations as signals that asset purchases have done the trick and an extension beyond March is unwarranted. In this context, Mario Draghi may signal the ECB’s intention to begin tapering when conditions allow, although explicit forward guidance is unlikely at this point. The rhetoric rather than the policy may therefore be the most interesting element of today’s announcement.

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:44am

Glencore! Of course. Nearly forgot.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 303.80, up 7.05 (+2.38%), High: 304.15, Low: 297.05, Volume: 28.31m
BE11:44am

Moscow dropped the apparently unilaterally overnight.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Which wasn't great timing, as it was apparently the Glencore Christmas party overnight.

BE11:45am

We eventually had a "okay, we know what it looks like but don't panic," statement out of Glencore a few hours later.

BE11:46am

Market rather more sanguine than I was expecting. I thought there would be some overlap with the BP shareholders who spent a few sleepless nighty due to Rosneft ......

11:46 am
BE11:47am

... however, capital outlay's minimal and the underlying stake is tiny.

BE11:47am

Here's Deutsche to explain the moving parts.

BE11:47am

As signaled by management at last week’s Investor Update, GLEN is keen to put more capital to work in marketing, and last night announced that it is participating in the Russian government’s monetization of a stake in Rosneft (Buy, TP 420 RUB). The government is selling a 19.5% stake to the Qatar Investment Authority and Glencore, valuing the stake at EUR ~10bn. Although GLEN’s equity participation in the deal is quite small, we think it clearly signals M&A is back on management’s agenda. We expect GLEN to pursue more deals, particularly on the marketing side (possibly through the new agriculture JV). We rate Glencore Hold as the shares are trading at our NPV-derived TP.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

"As signaled by management at last week’s Investor Update" ... heh. As if this was anything other than leftfield.

BE11:48am

The deal (not yet finalized) will see Glencore and QIA acquire a 19.5% stake in Rosneft from the Russian government. Glencore will only be injecting EUR 300mn cash into the entity and thus will only have an indirect ~0.5% stake in Rosneft as a result. QIA and non-recourse bank financing will fund the rest of the deal. GLEN has secured a new five year off-take agreement representing ~220k bbl/d and a strategic partnership will offer additional opportunities around infrastructure, logistics, and global trading. A limited liability structure for the vehicle will also ring-fence GLEN from its indirect stake and will not have recourse to GLEN.

BE11:48am

Haven’t we seen this before? Sort of...
In late 2012, Glencore and Vitol inked a long-term crude supply agreement with Rosneft where the two trading houses agreed to prepayment of 67mn tonnes of crude over five years (~260kbbl/d average, ~180kbbl/d GLEN attributable share). The prepayment was financed by a bank consortium. However, GLEN’s USD 500mn proportion of the prepayment was sold on during 2014.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Understanding the earnings impact is relatively difficult given we don’t know the off-take terms. However, GLEN currently markets ~1.6mbbl/d (crude) and energy marketing (inc coal), represents ~6% of EBITDA FY17e, so any uplift is likely to be relatively small.

BE11:49am

After a bruising 2015 forced GLEN management to raise equity and sell assets, it now appears ready to put more capital to work in marketing. Although any one deal might not be large in Marketing, they can add up. For example, in 2015 GLEN acquired two oilseed crushing operations in Canada and Germany, totaling USD ~300mn. Additionally, we think this raises further questions regarding how GLEN’s new net debt/EBITDA limit of 2x will be balanced in future between the Marketing and Industrial divisions.

BE11:50am

..... Dunno. I get the "low reward for low risk" argument here, but it seems to ignore the rather more intangible risks of being a Rosneft shareholder in an increasingly complex and bellicose world.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

(And I apologise for the lapse into journalist-ese with "increasingly complex and bellicose world".)

BE11:52am

.... here's Morgan Stanley as well.

BE11:53am

(@Pharma: that's certainly one way to read it. Though putting a prediction on Trump challenges the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test.)

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Potential equity stake of c. 0.54% in Rosneft with 220k/boe
daily offtake agreement for five years is part of normal course
of business for Marketing. At USD323 million this can easily
be financed by cash flows with shares trading on spot FCF
yield of 13.8% in 2017, we estimate.
Glencore has announced it is negotiating an (indirect) equity investment of 0.54% in Rosneft, the Russian oil producer for EUR300 million (USD323 million). The price paid would imply a market value close to the current market cap of US$58.5 billion. It can easily finance this from either FCF (13.8% yield on spot for 2017e) or available credit lines, in our view.
Glencore's indirect equity stake is part of a consortium that will take a 19.5% equity stake in total (including Glencore's 0.54%). The equity stake will be placed in a special purpose vehicle (SPV) which is largely financed debt (exact proportion of debt is not disclosed). The debt in the SPV is non recourse to Glencore. It has provided certain guarantees related to the SPV but is looking to hedge the risks coming from those guarantees with financial institutions.
A 220kboe per day crude oil off take agreement for five years is part of the potential transaction. In 1H2016 Glencore traded 2.2 million boe per day of crude oil and another 2.2 million boe per day of oil products on top of that. Between 2012-1H2016 Glencore generated EBITDA per boe of USD0.55 (assuming no profit or losses were made in coal trading) ranging from USD0.26-0.85/boe. Using this average implies extra EBITDA of USD0.221 billion cumulative over five years. A small but positive increment to our current cumulative spot EBITDA estimate of USD64 billion (including share of associates).
Equity and debt investments in suppliers as part of offtake agreements are normal course of business for Glencore's Marketing operation. Glencore also has a long history of fixed asset investments in Russia. In 2015 it swapped loans into a 46% equity stake (with over 20% of the voting rights) with a book value of USD0.7 billion in OAO NK Russneft, another Russian oil and gas producer. It also owns a 8.8% equity stake in Rusal, a top three global aluminium producer with most of its assets in Russia.

undefined
BE11:55am

Further to requests: Novae.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Profit warning.

Novae Group PLC (NVA:LSE): Last: 673.50, down 161.5 (-19.34%), High: 743.50, Low: 655.00, Volume: 304.58k
BE11:55am

Having already warned in November, I think.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Same reasons. Individual risk losses and catastrophe losses running ahead of model.

BE11:56am

There's also a bit of rejigging with deferred acquisition costs, which kinda makes sense in context I guess.

BE11:57am

Now targeting a combined ratio of 98-100%, providing nothing unexpected happens in December.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Here's RBC.

BE11:57am

As a result of the change to guidance we increase our combined ratio forecast to 99.5% for 2016 from our previous 97.3% estimate. The company also commented that despite the incidence of larger risk losses and catastrophe losses increasing, the attritional loss ratio has remained steady despite pricing pressures.

BE11:57am

Although increasing bond yields are positive for insurers, with the Lloyd's insurers, the decline in the value of the bonds is recognised through earnings. As a result, the near 30% increase in 2 year government bond yields since the US election has led to a significant reduction in investment income for Novae in 2016. As a result we reduce our 2016E investment income expectation by 17.5% to £31m.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Following a review of the company’s accounting policies, Novae has amended its accounting treatment for deferred acquisition costs, which is subjective in nature as it is based on a number of factors including the expected earnings pattern of insurance contracts. This has resulted in a write-down of c.£17m deferred acquisition costs (relating to a period in the region of ten years) to the 2016 opening balance sheet. For the same reason, the deferred acquisition cost charge for 2016 will increase by c. £5m (reflected within the new combined ratio guidance by c.80bps based on our estimates).

BE11:58am

Following on from the trading statement, we make a reduction to our 2016E profit before tax of 26%. In addition, we reduce our 2017-18E earnings by 4% on average reflecting higher combined ratios and lower growth than we had previously expected. As a result of the changes to our estimates, we reduce our price target to 900p from 925p.

BE11:59am

And, oh, a Canaccord downgrade.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Novae warned on Thursday morning that elevated levels of large risk and catastrophe losses flagged at Q3 had continued into Q4. It now expects a full year combined ratio in the range of 98-100%, against 96.1% at H1 and our 96.4% FY forecast. £5m of this impact is to come from an accounting reappraisal of treatment of deferred acquisition cost policy. A bigger £17m hit from this accounting will also be taken to the opening 2016 NAV, obviously impacting forecasts for closing NAV, but with no impact on cashflow or economic capital. There will also be an additional hit to profits from the sharp rise in bond yields since Trump’s election – US government yields in the three to five year range have risen c.30%. This also should not impact economic capital negatively.

BE11:59am

Confluence of large losses, higher yields and DAC hit
Management said that the additional cost of large risk losses did not relate to a single new event – Hurricane Matthew is now looking at the top end of the £10-15m range given, while Novae has incurred losses from the New Zealand earthquake, and other losses have also moved against the group. The statement makes the point that the attritional loss ratio has not deteriorated, and we note also that none of the risk losses have come from new initiatives by class that have driven top-line growth. We expect peers to have had comparable experience. The same will be true of the investment income hit, albeit Novae is slightly longer duration in liabilities than its quoted peers. The DAC issue came to light as part of a regular accounting review and relates in part to some items that should not have been treated as acquisition costs (eg some professional fees and claims handling costs) and some bona fide costs that had been deferred for too long (ie into year three when policy earns in years one and two).

BE11:59am

Material cuts to 2016E EPS and tangible NAV
We have made a material cut to 2016E EPS of 40%, based on a 99.5% combined ratio – c.one-third of the cut is due to lower investment income (this could still move materially by year-end). While management has said that 2016 large losses will not impact on underwriting strategy going forward, we have assumed a 0.5% higher loss ratio going forward. This impact has been partly offset by higher yields going forward, for a 3% cut to 2017E and 2018E EPS. With the dividend over 2x covered, we leave DPS forecasts unchanged. Note also the 11% cut to tangible NAV per share, of which c.4% is due to the £17m DAC writedown to book.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Time will be needed to rebuild performance; downgrade to HOLD, TP to 800p
We are disappointed the 9m performance has worsened in the final quarter. We believe it has been a bad, but not exceptional, year for large losses at an industry level. NVA is likely more exposed than quoted Lloyd’s peers due to its narrower scope of business.
On a material cut to NAV, and modestly lowered earnings, we see limited positive catalysts until full year results at the earliest. On an unchanged target multiple of 1.45x 2016E tangible NAV per share (versus peers on 1.7-1.8x, albeit consensus NAVs do likely need to come down for higher bond yields), we lower our price target from 900p to 800p, and our recommendation to HOLD (Buy). Our new price target equates to 12x 2017E EPS from 13x versus peers trading on 12-14x, for a 4% yield, with peers yielding under 3%.

undefined
BE12:01pm

Midday already, and we haven't even mentioned yet another profit warning from Capita.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Didn't we write about this very recently?

BE12:02pm

Yes. Yes we did: https://www.ft.com...-961e-a1acd97f622d

BE12:02pm

Well done to HSBC for timing that one. We don't have the rights issue yet, but it remains a not implausible endgame.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

For the moment, we have disposals instead.

BE12:04pm

If I remember HSBC's note correctly, it argued that disposals would have very little positive effect on leverage as that's what happens when you're a distressed seller.

BE12:04pm

But I don't have it to hand. Instead, here's Goldman.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Capita issued a pre-close trading update this morning. The company guided to underlying 2016 PBT of £515 mn, effectively cutting its already lowered guidance from the end of September of £535-555 mn by another 6% at the mid-point. Additionally, the company announced £50 mn of restructuring costs to be charged to the P&L in 2016. For 2017, Capita expects a similar trading environment to 2016 as the full effect of the weaker environment will annualise. Capita also stated that it will dispose the majority of its Asset Services businesses (ex mortgage/banking services) and other trading businesses that are expected to contribute around £70 mn in operating profit in aggregate in 2016; Capita expects to complete these disposals during 2H17. The company now expects net 2016 debt/EBITDA of 2.9x; following a successful disposal, net debt would fall to the lower end of its 2.0-2.5x range.

BE12:05pm

We view this as a mixed announcement. We believe the market already saw risks of more profitability headwinds for FY2016, but uncertainties pertaining to the looming restructuring costs are now addressed, which could alleviate investor concerns. However, the still elevated leverage and continued weaker growth outlook for the market remains a concern. We expect more comments from management on the rational of the disposal of the higher-margin/return part of the CAS business and more comments on cyclical parts of the group like staffing and hardware reselling.

BE12:05pm

We remain Neutral-rated. We value Capita at 10x 2018E EV/EBITDA, reflecting growth and capital intensity, consistent with our broader business services valuation methodology. We also add to our target price the value from potential uses of cash which also includes a potential equity raise, and then discount back by one year to reach our 12-month price target of 771p. Key risks: slower/faster macro growth in the UK, M&A execution, failure of cost controls, bigger litigation expenses.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

And Barclays .......

BE12:06pm

Bottom line, £580m of EBITA, less £70m from disposals and c£60m of interest costs, leaves PBT of c£450m which, all-else-equal, equates to EPS of 54p.

· Since September’s trading update, performance in IT Enterprise services has weakened further. Post organisational changes it expects performance to improve over 2017.

· Additionally, as a result of some clients' own cost saving measures, Capita has recently experienced lower volumes of discretionary spend in a number of the Company's other trading businesses. The bid pipeline stands at £3.8bn (£5.1bn July). After a year of delayed contract decisions, management expect BPO markets to become more active in the longer term .

· Small and medium sized M&A is expected to continue, albeit at a lower rate over 2017/18.

Dividend is the support.

· The company is maintaining the 31.7p dividend for FY16 and expects to hold it flat for FY17e – providing a yield of c6%.

· The shares trade on c8.5x FY17e EBITA and c8x FY17e PE (on Reuters consensus figures).
